metadata.titleEn: The dataset of thermokarst lakes in the Hoh Xil Region (1980s-2018)
metadata.description: Based on the Landsat data from 1980s to 2018, the NDWI water body index method was adopted, the method of combining machine interpretation with manual interpretation was adopted, and then the distribution data set of thermokarst lakes in Hoh Xil region was produced after manual visual interpretation and correction. The data set covers an area of 830000 square kilometers in the Hoh Xil region, and includes three years of lake distribution data, namely, 1980 s thermokarst lake distribution data, 2000 thermokarst lake distribution data and 2018 thermokarst lake distribution data. This data set can provide data basis for lake research and engineering disaster prevention and reduction in Hoh Xil region.

background: A thermokarst lake is generally defined as a lake that occupies a closed basin and is created by the massive melting of ground ice in ice-rich permafrost regions, which has a great impact on regional hydro-ecological equilibrium and permafrost-engineering infrastructure facilities. Global warming and increasing human activities have been accompanied by permafrost degradation and glacier retreat in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau (QTP). The QTP, known as the Third Pole, has a permafrost area of 115.02 × 104 km2, accounting for nearly 46% of its total area. Global warming in recent decades has been most pronounced at high altitude and has accelerated permafrost degradation. Scholars have demonstrated that thermokarst lakes are sensitive indicators of climate change and permafrost degradation. Recently, permafrost degradation at the global scale has attracted wide attention resulting from its remarkable environmental effects. Infrastructure stability, food security, water supply, and hydrological and habitat functions may be extensively influenced when a major area of permafrost becomes degraded.
research objective: To address the evolution of thermokarst lakes in the QTP, visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index were applied to extract the water area based on Landsat data from the 1980s to 2020. Therefore, we quantified changes in thermokarst lakes from the 1980s to 2020, using satellite image interpretation and object-based long-term lake detection to accurately understand changes in thermokarst lakes across the QTP.
challenges: As the aforementioned results suggest, previous research about thermokarst lake dynamics was insufficient.
methods: In this study, a total of 138 × 40 Landsat images from the 1980s to 2020 were selected. All datasets were registered to the Albers Conical Equal Area coordinate system zones 26N–40N, and elevation was referenced to WGS 1984 data. In this study, permafrost data for the 1980s was derived from the National Cryosphere Desert Data Center, and the permafrost dataset for 2017 was provided by the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center. In this study, we identified thermokarst lakes as those lakes distributed in permafrost areas and not directly connected with rivers. To ensure the accuracy of the lake extraction, we checked the lakes one by one after the mechanical interpretation.
dataset: In this study, a total of 138 × 40 Landsat images from the 1980s to 2020 were selected. Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI images with 30 m spatial resolution are readily available from the 1980s onward and can reveal long-term changes in land cover. Elevation information was downloaded from the ASTER Global Digital Elevation Model (GDEM) with 90 m spatial resolution and was extracted by the QTP boundary shapefile mask. Long-term (1980–2020) temperature and precipitation data were available from “The spatial dataset of climate on the Tibetan Plateau,” hosted by the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
findings: The results indicate that thermokarst lake area was reduced from 932.5 km2 to 799.25 km2 from the 1980s to 1990. From 1990 to 2020, the number and area of lakes grew substantially, with the number increasing from 66506 to 120374 and the area increasing by 113.14% (932.5 km2 in 1980s and 1703.56 km2 in 2020).

Concept Completion.Answer: Visual interpretation, Modified Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI)

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that combines machine interpretation with manual interpretation for mapping lake distributions in permafrost areas?
Example.Answer: The data collection method involves using the NDWI water index method applied to Landsat data from the 1980s to 2018, combining machine interpretation with manual interpretation, followed by manual visual interpretation correction to map lake distributions in the Hoh Xil region.

Example.Question: What is an example of a methodological challenge encountered when studying thermokarst lake dynamics using remote sensing data?
Example.Answer: A methodological challenge includes ensuring the accuracy of lake extraction, which was addressed by checking the lakes one by one after mechanical interpretation to confirm their distribution in permafrost areas and lack of direct connection with rivers.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset used to analyze long-term changes in thermokarst lakes on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset includes 138 × 40 Landsat images from the 1980s to 2020, registered to the Albers Conical Equal Area coordinate system, with elevation referenced to WGS 1984 data, used to study changes in thermokarst lakes on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection method used for identifying thermokarst lakes in permafrost regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: Landsat imagery, Modified Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI), mechanical interpretation, manual verification, Albers Conical Equal Area coordinate system, WGS 1984, permafrost datasets from national data centers

Feature Specification.Question: What potential datasets could be utilized to enhance the understanding of thermokarst lake changes in permafrost regions?
Feature Specification.Answer: long-term Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI images, elevation data from ASTER Global Digital Elevation Model (GDEM), climate datasets such as temperature and precipitation records from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center

Quantification.Question: How many thermokarst lakes were there in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau in 2020?

Definition.Question: What does the term 'NDWI water index method' mean in the context of thermokarst lake data collection?
Definition.Answer: The NDWI water index method refers to the use of the Normalized Difference Water Index, which is applied for extracting water bodies from Landsat data. It involves calculating the index to identify and map water features in satellite imagery, facilitating the detection and monitoring of thermokarst lakes.

Definition.Question: What does 'object-based long-term lake detection' mean in studying thermokarst lakes?
Definition.Answer: Object-based long-term lake detection involves using satellite image interpretation techniques to identify and monitor lake changes over time. It focuses on recognizing lake objects within satellite images and tracking their evolution across multiple decades to understand the dynamics of thermokarst lakes on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do datasets sourced from the National Cryosphere Desert Data Center for the 1980s differ from those provided by the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center for 2017 in terms of supporting thermokarst lake research?
Comparison.Answer: Datasets from the National Cryosphere Desert Data Center for the 1980s provide historical context for permafrost conditions, while those from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center for 2017 offer updated permafrost data. The latter may feature improved accuracy and resolution, reflecting technological advancements and more recent environmental conditions, thus enhancing support for current thermokarst lake research.

Interpretation.Question: How can the use of NDWI water index method contribute to improving the accuracy and reliability of dataset creation for thermokarst lake distribution in permafrost regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The NDWI water index method facilitates the extraction of water bodies from satellite images, which is crucial for accurately identifying thermokarst lakes. By combining this method with machine and manual interpretation, researchers can improve the accuracy and reliability of datasets, as demonstrated in the collection of data from the 1980s to 2018 using Landsat images.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might satellite image interpretation and object-based detection methods complement each other in understanding long-term changes in thermokarst lakes?
Interpretation.Answer: Satellite image interpretation allows for the extraction of water areas over time, while object-based detection methods provide a framework for tracking individual lake changes. By using both approaches, researchers can gain a comprehensive view of lake dynamics and better quantify long-term changes in thermokarst lakes, as shown by the increase in lake area and number from the 1980s to 2020.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately interpreting thermokarst lake dynamics using satellite imagery?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in accurately interpreting thermokarst lake dynamics using satellite imagery arise from limitations in previous research on thermokarst lake dynamics and the need for precise visual interpretation methods, such as the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index, to extract accurate water area data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to combine machine interpretation with manual correction when developing a dataset of thermokarst lake distributions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is important to combine machine interpretation with manual correction when developing a dataset of thermokarst lake distributions to ensure accuracy, as automatic methods may not always accurately capture the nuances of lake boundaries, necessitating post-processing manual visual interpretation corrections.

Causal Consequence.Question: If visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index are used extensively for extracting water areas, what are the potential consequences on the accuracy and reliability of thermokarst lake datasets over time?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index can lead to more accurate extraction of water areas, as they allow for precise identification and quantification of changes in thermokarst lakes over time. This approach helps in accurately understanding changes across the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau by ensuring that lakes are checked individually after mechanical interpretation, which improves reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What might be the possible outcomes of integrating long-term climate datasets with Landsat images when studying thermokarst lake dynamics on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating long-term climate datasets with Landsat images can lead to a comprehensive understanding of the factors influencing thermokarst lake dynamics. It enables researchers to correlate changes in lake areas with climatic variables such as temperature and precipitation, offering insights into the impacts of climate change on permafrost degradation and lake expansion.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to combine machine and manual interpretation methods when analyzing thermokarst lake distributions over several decades?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Combining machine and manual interpretation ensures higher accuracy in detecting lake distributions, as machine interpretation can be cross-verified and corrected through visual inspection, thus addressing challenges of previous insufficient research on lake dynamics.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the rationale behind selecting a long-term dataset from the 1980s to 2020 for studying thermokarst lake changes?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of a long-term dataset allows researchers to observe and quantify trends and changes in thermokarst lake areas over several decades, providing insights into the effects of climate change and permafrost degradation, as well as the implications for regional infrastructure and environmental stability.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodology is employed to ensure the accuracy of thermokarst lake extraction using Landsat data from the 1980s to 2020?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the accuracy of lake extraction, a combination of visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) is applied. Additionally, the lakes are checked one by one after mechanical interpretation to confirm their accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can Landsat images be utilized to detect long-term changes in thermokarst lakes across the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI images with 30 m spatial resolution, available from the 1980s onward, are used to reveal long-term changes in land cover. The images are registered to the Albers Conical Equal Area coordinate system, and elevation data from the ASTER Global Digital Elevation Model (GDEM) is integrated to assist in detecting changes in thermokarst lakes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are taken to differentiate thermokarst lakes from other water bodies in permafrost regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Thermokarst lakes are identified as lakes distributed in permafrost areas that are not directly connected with rivers. This differentiation involves visual interpretation and mechanical checking, ensuring that only those lakes meeting these criteria are included in the dataset.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enabled the use of satellite image interpretation for tracking changes in thermokarst lakes over decades?
Enablement.Answer: The availability of Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI images with 30 m spatial resolution from the 1980s onward enabled long-term monitoring and change detection of thermokarst lakes. These technological advancements allowed researchers to apply visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index to accurately track changes over time.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multiple datasets, such as climate data and elevation models, enable a comprehensive analysis of thermokarst lake dynamics?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of diverse datasets, including Landsat images, elevation data from the ASTER Global Digital Elevation Model, and long-term temperature and precipitation data from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center, provides a multifaceted view of thermokarst lake dynamics. These datasets help to understand the environmental factors and changes impacting the lakes over time.

Enablement.Question: In what ways did the combination of machine interpretation and manual visual checks enhance the accuracy of thermokarst lake identification in the data collection process?
Enablement.Answer: The combination of machine interpretation using the NDWI water index method with subsequent manual visual checks allowed for enhanced accuracy in identifying thermokarst lakes. This dual approach ensured that each lake was verified individually, minimizing errors and improving the reliability of the extracted data.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) be insufficient for accurately identifying thermokarst lakes in permafrost regions?
Expectation.Answer: Previous research on thermokarst lake dynamics was considered insufficient, indicating potential limitations of traditional methods like NDWI in capturing changes in thermokarst lakes, especially given the complexity and sensitivity of these lakes to climate change and permafrost degradation.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could arise in the manual verification process of lake identification after mechanical interpretation, and how might these affect expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: The manual verification of lakes after mechanical interpretation is crucial to ensure accuracy. However, inconsistencies or errors in manual interpretation could lead to discrepancies in expected lake distribution data, particularly in large datasets spanning multiple decades.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated impacts of using Landsat images with varying spatial resolutions over different decades on the consistency and reliability of long-term thermokarst lake monitoring?
Expectation.Answer: Landsat images from the 1980s to 2020 with a 30 m spatial resolution are used to reveal long-term changes, yet variations in image quality and resolution over decades could affect the consistency and reliability of monitoring thermokarst lake changes, possibly leading to challenges in tracking subtle changes or smaller lakes.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of combining mechanical and visual interpretation techniques in the data collection process for thermokarst lakes?
Judgmental.Answer: The combination of mechanical and visual interpretation techniques appears effective in ensuring accuracy, as it includes manual verification post-mechanical interpretation, which helps address potential errors from automated methods alone.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how a dataset on thermokarst lakes can be compiled over several decades using satellite imagery.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset on thermokarst lakes is compiled using Landsat satellite imagery from the 1980s to 2018, employing the NDWI water index method combined with machine and manual interpretation. The dataset includes lake distribution data for different years and is manually corrected for accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why the evolution of thermokarst lakes could be an indicator of climate change.
Assertion.Answer: Thermokarst lakes are sensitive indicators of climate change and permafrost degradation. Their changes can reflect the impacts of global warming, especially in high-altitude regions like the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau, where permafrost degradation and glacier retreat are prominent.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand what the challenges are in using satellite imagery for tracking changes in thermokarst lakes.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in using satellite imagery for tracking thermokarst lakes include ensuring the accuracy of lake extraction and the need for manual verification of results after mechanical interpretation. Previous research on thermokarst lake dynamics has been insufficient, highlighting the need for precise methodologies.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection methods used for capturing thermokarst lake area changes from the 1980s to 2020 in the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involved using Landsat TM/ETM+/OLI images with 30 m spatial resolution to reveal long-term changes in land cover. Visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index were applied to extract water areas. The study utilized 138 × 40 Landsat images registered to the Albers Conical Equal Area coordinate system, and elevation data referenced to WGS 1984. Permafrost data for the 1980s was sourced from the National Cryosphere Desert Data Center, while the 2017 dataset came from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in previous research on thermokarst lake dynamics and how they were addressed in recent studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Previous research on thermokarst lake dynamics was considered insufficient. Recent studies addressed these challenges by applying visual interpretation and the Modified Normalized Difference Water Index to improve accuracy in extracting water areas. The studies involved manually checking each lake after mechanical interpretation to ensure accuracy and used long-term satellite data to quantify changes in thermokarst lakes more effectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential sources or strategies to expand or refine datasets related to thermokarst lakes in permafrost regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential sources or strategies to expand or refine datasets related to thermokarst lakes could include acquiring additional satellite imagery with higher spatial and temporal resolution, integrating other remote sensing technologies like LiDAR or radar, and utilizing updated climate and hydrological data from national or international data centers. Collaboration with local research institutions to gather ground-truth data for validation and the incorporation of machine learning techniques for more automated and accurate data interpretation could also be beneficial.
